title: ok
content:
ok this is the first personal Web
import torchimport torch.nn as nnclass ResidualBlock(nn.Module):    def __init__(self, channels):        super().__init__()        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(channels, channels, 3, padding=1)        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(channels, channels, 3, padding=1)        self.relu = nn.ReLU()        def forward(self, x):        residual = x  # Save the input        out = self.relu(self.conv1(x))        out = self.conv2(out)        out += residual  # Add the skip connection        return self.relu(out)

The magic is in line out += residualâ€”the skip connection that makes deep networks trainable.

Key TakeawaysHereâ€™s what we can learn from ResNets:

Incremental improvement beats complete rewrites
Skip connections help information flow freely
Identity mappings preserve what already works
Depth becomes possible when gradients can flow


The CSS AnalogyWhen debugging a stylesheet, think like a ResNet:

Donâ€™t delete the existing styles (thatâ€™s your identity mapping)
Append corrections that target specific issues
Use specificity to override only whatâ€™s broken
Test incrementally after each residual fix


â€œThe best code change is the smallest one that solves the problem.â€


ConclusionWhether youâ€™re training neural networks or styling web pages, the residual approach keeps you grounded. Start with what works, identify whatâ€™s broken, and apply the minimum correction needed.
Next time you face a complex bug, ask yourself: â€œWhatâ€™s the residual?â€

title: Hello Universe
content:
ğŸŒŒ Welcome to the UniverseThis is a test post to verify that our Glassmorphism theme is working correctly across all pages.

Testing H2 HeadingsIf you can read this heading clearly against the aurora background, the white text styling is working. The heading should have a subtle gradient effect (cyan to purple).
Testing H3 HeadingsThis is a third-level heading. It should also be clearly visible with good contrast.

Body Text TestThis paragraph tests the body font. Weâ€™re using Outfit as our interface fontâ€”a clean, modern sans-serif thatâ€™s easy to read on screens. No Times New Roman here!
Hereâ€™s some bold text and italic text to check styling. And hereâ€™s a link to the homepage to test link colors.

â€œThe best code is no code at all.â€ â€” Jeff Atwood
This blockquote should have a glassmorphism background with a cyan left border.


Code Block TestHereâ€™s a JavaScript code block to test syntax highlighting and contrast:
// Galaxy Ripple Effectfunction createRipple(x, y) {  const ripple = document.createElement('span');  ripple.className = 'click-ripple';  ripple.style.left = x + 'px';  ripple.style.top = y + 'px';  document.body.appendChild(ripple);    setTimeout(() => ripple.remove(), 500);}document.addEventListener('click', (e) => {  createRipple(e.clientX, e.clientY);});

And some inline code: const theme = 'cosmic-void';

List TestUnordered List
First item with white text
Second item to check spacing
Third item with a link

Ordered List
First numbered item
Second numbered item
Third numbered item


SummaryIf all the elements above are:

âœ… Readable (white text on glass)
âœ… Properly styled (Outfit font)
âœ… Inside a glassmorphism container
âœ… Consistent with the homepage cards

Then our theme is working correctly! ğŸ‰

title: The Art of Residual Networks
content:
The Art of Residual NetworksIn the world of deep learning, Residual Networks (ResNets) revolutionized how we think about training very deep neural networks. But the concept of â€œresidualsâ€ isnâ€™t limited to AIâ€”itâ€™s a powerful mental model for problem-solving in general.

What Are Residuals?
â€œInstead of learning the full transformation, learn only the difference between input and output.â€â€” The ResNet Philosophy

The core insight is elegant: rather than asking a layer to learn a complex function $H(x)$ from scratch, we ask it to learn only the residual $F(x) = H(x) - x$. The final output becomes $F(x) + x$.
This same principle applies to debugging CSS. Donâ€™t rewrite everythingâ€”find the residual correction.

Applying Residual Thinking to CodeHereâ€™s a simple Python example of a residual block:
import torchimport torch.nn as nnclass ResidualBlock(nn.Module):    def __init__(self, channels):        super().__init__()        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(channels, channels, 3, padding=1)        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(channels, channels, 3, padding=1)        self.relu = nn.ReLU()        def forward(self, x):        residual = x  # Save the input        out = self.relu(self.conv1(x))        out = self.conv2(out)        out += residual  # Add the skip connection        return self.relu(out)

The magic is in line out += residualâ€”the skip connection that makes deep networks trainable.

Key TakeawaysHereâ€™s what we can learn from ResNets:

Incremental improvement beats complete rewrites
Skip connections help information flow freely
Identity mappings preserve what already works
Depth becomes possible when gradients can flow


The CSS AnalogyWhen debugging a stylesheet, think like a ResNet:

Donâ€™t delete the existing styles (thatâ€™s your identity mapping)
Append corrections that target specific issues
Use specificity to override only whatâ€™s broken
Test incrementally after each residual fix


â€œThe best code change is the smallest one that solves the problem.â€


ConclusionWhether youâ€™re training neural networks or styling web pages, the residual approach keeps you grounded. Start with what works, identify whatâ€™s broken, and apply the minimum correction needed.
Next time you face a complex bug, ask yourself: â€œWhatâ€™s the residual?â€
